study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between dietary patterns, particularly high-fat and dairy intake, and gut microbiome composition in relation to immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy outcomes in NSCLC patients.
results_summary: The study found that the hyperprogressive disease (HPD) group had higher food pattern scores associated with increased fat and dairy intake, suggesting a potential link between dairy consumption and poorer ICI therapy outcomes. However, no direct causal relationship was established.
population_specificity: 95 patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) undergoing ICI therapy.
study_duration: Dietary patterns were assessed for 3 days before ICI therapy; follow-up duration not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of dairy proteins (caseins and whey proteins) and nondairy proteins as delivery systems for phenolic compounds to enhance their solubility, stability, and bioavailability.
results_summary: The study found that dairy and nondairy proteins can effectively encapsulate phenolic compounds, improving their delivery and health benefits, but noted that preservation techniques and molecular interactions vary case-by-case. Safety and regulatory aspects for nanoproducts were highlighted as needing further standardization.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop Moroccan nutritional recommendations for patients with osteosarcopenia, emphasizing the role of dairy in a balanced diet.
results_summary: The study recommended maintaining a balanced intake of dairy products, along with adequate calcium and vitamin D, while evaluating the benefit-risk ratio of calcium supplementation. Dairy was included as part of the Mediterranean diet, which was advised for osteosarcopenia patients.
population_specificity: Moroccan patients with osteosarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of chimeric endolysins and their synergistic use with biofilm-reducing agents to control biofilm formation in the dairy industry.
results_summary: The study highlights the potential of chimeric endolysins and synergistic approaches to improve lytic activity against bacterial biofilms, suggesting their applicability in dairy and other industries.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on in vitro and in vivo experiments)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of bovine milk-derived extracellular vesicles (MEVs) as nanomedicine carriers and their possible connections to immune regulation and autoimmune diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights MEVs as promising nanomedicine carriers due to their low immunogenicity and immune-regulatory properties, but notes potential concerns regarding their effects on different organs and accumulation in the body. It also suggests further exploration of MEVs' role in autoimmune diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human application implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of a maternal dairy-free diet on alleviating colic symptoms in infants and whether parental atopy history influenced colic severity or treatment efficacy.
results_summary: A maternal dairy-free diet significantly reduced colic symptoms in infants, regardless of parental atopy history. The severity of colic was unrelated to parental atopy, suggesting improvement may be due to milk intolerance rather than allergy.
population_specificity: Breastfed infants with infantile colic (average age 28.77 ± 9.99 days) in Arak, Iran.
effective_dosage: Dairy products were removed from the mother's diet (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the molecular mechanisms of different types of regulated cell death (RCD) and their regulatory roles in mastitis to explore new targeted treatment approaches.
results_summary: The study highlights the critical role of regulated cell death (RCD) in mastitis and suggests that targeting these mechanisms could provide new therapeutic strategies for treating the disease.
population_specificity: Dairy cattle affected by mastitis (implied by the focus on mastitis in the dairy industry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of high-protein diets (HPDs), particularly those excluding dairy, in reducing hyperglycemia in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that HPDs, especially Paleolithic diets excluding dairy, were effective in reducing hyperglycemia in T2DM patients, attributed to higher-quality protein sources and exclusion of dairy, grains, and refined sugars.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HPDs defined as >30% protein or >1.0 g/Kg/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between dairy consumption and anthropometric, metabolic, and hormonal outcomes in women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found limited evidence linking dairy consumption to PCOS, but clinical trials showed that a low-dairy/low-starch diet significantly improved weight, BMI, waist circumference, insulin levels, HbA1c, and testosterone levels in PCOS patients. No significant effects were observed for fasting glucose, 2-hour glucose, fat mass, or free testosterone.
population_specificity: Women with Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the health effects of whole plant foods versus animal foods (including dairy) on overweight, obesity, and related chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that replacing animal foods (including dairy) with whole plant foods is associated with improved cardiometabolic risk factors and lower risk of chronic diseases and mortality. Dairy was not specifically highlighted as beneficial compared to whole plant foods.
population_specificity: General population, focusing on individuals with overweight or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential therapeutic benefits of targeting the Nrf2/Keap1/NF-κB signaling pathway to alleviate LPS-induced endometritis in dairy animals.
results_summary: The review highlights that bioactive compounds enhancing Nrf2 signaling and suppressing NF-κB activation can reduce oxidative stress and inflammation in endometrial cells, offering protective effects against endometritis. It suggests these compounds could supplement or replace traditional antibiotic treatments.
population_specificity: Perinatal dairy animals (livestock)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of probiotic ayran (containing Lactobacillus acidophilus and Bifidobacterium bifidum) reduces gingival inflammation and experimental gingivitis compared to regular ayran.
results_summary: Probiotic ayran significantly reduced plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, and MMP-8 levels compared to the control group after a 5-day experimental gingivitis period, though no significant difference was observed in probing pocket depth.
population_specificity: 54 volunteer students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential cardiovascular benefits of nutrients found in dairy waste, particularly whey protein, based on animal and clinical evidence.
results_summary: The study found that whey protein from dairy waste may lower cardiovascular disease risk by improving lipid profile, reducing blood pressure, enhancing glucose and insulin regulation, and decreasing inflammation. However, intervention studies were limited in participant numbers and duration.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk of cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review lactoferrin's antiviral effects, particularly against HPV and other viruses, and its potential health benefits as a component of dairy.
results_summary: Lactoferrin demonstrated significant antiviral effects against HPV, coronaviruses, and hepatitis viruses by inhibiting viral entry and stimulating immune responses. The study highlighted lactoferrin's multifunctional properties, including antiviral, anti-inflammatory, and immune-modulatory effects.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish consensus on dietary strategies, including dairy consumption, for preventing metabolic dysfunction-associated fatty liver disease (MAFLD).
results_summary: The study recommended increasing consumption of low-fat or fat-free dairy products as part of a balanced diet for MAFLD prevention, alongside other dietary modifications like whole grains and plant-based proteins.
population_specificity: International experts in hepatology, gastroenterology, dietetics, endocrinology, and other medical specialties.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate molecular farming technologies and identify opportunities in dairy proteins, food enzymes, collagen, and cellular agriculture.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Dairy's effects, only mentioning the evaluation of molecular farming technologies and market potential.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the variability in commercial MFGM ingredients from dairy sources and their potential health benefits, particularly in infant nutrition.
results_summary: The study found that MFGM supplementation is associated with improved cognitive development, immune function, and gastrointestinal health in infants, supported by clinical studies. It also highlighted the impact of processing methods on the bioactive properties of MFGM.
population_specificity: Infants (early life nutrition)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the origins of the H5N1 outbreak in dairy cows and assess diagnostic capacity for HPAI H5N1.
results_summary: The study detailed the H5N1 outbreak in dairy cows, highlighted gaps in commercially available diagnostic assays, and emphasized the need for collaboration among agencies and laboratories.
population_specificity: Dairy cows and individuals with close contact to infected herds and poultry flocks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize how different thermal treatments affect milk's nutritional and sensory properties, safety, and quality.
results_summary: The study found that ultra-short-time processing is comparable to pasteurization in specific parameters like whey protein behavior and heat-induced markers, while thermal treatments generally influence milk's nutritional and sensory properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent research on the role of the TLR2/TLR4/NF-κB signaling pathway in mastitis and explore potential therapeutic strategies targeting this pathway.
results_summary: The study found that activation of TLR2/TLR4 leads to proinflammatory cytokine production, exacerbating mastitis via the NF-κB pathway, and identified bioactive compounds and probiotics as potential therapeutic agents targeting this pathway.
population_specificity: Dairy cows with mastitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the presence and effects of melatonin in bovine milk, focusing on its potential as a natural bioactive molecule for improving sleep and overall well-being.
results_summary: The study found that melatonin in bovine milk varies by milking time (higher at night), reduces cortisol, acts as an antioxidant and anti-inflammatory agent, and supports immune and gastrointestinal health. UHT treatment does not significantly affect melatonin content, but further research on processing stability is needed.
population_specificity: Dairy cows and, by implication, human consumers of melatonin-rich milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the applications and properties of flaxseed mucilage (FSM) in dairy and food products, focusing on its functional benefits and potential for pharmaceutical use.
results_summary: The study found that FSM improves gelling ability, optical properties, taste, and user compliance in dairy products and serves as a versatile agent in pharmaceutical preparations. It also highlighted FSM's potential for targeted drug delivery due to its pH-responsive properties and biocompatibility.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the correlations between hypertriglyceridemia and lifestyle factors, including milk and dairy product consumption.
results_summary: The study found that milk and dairy product consumption was associated with hypertriglyceridemia, but the nature of this association (positive or negative) was not specified. The abstract does not provide detailed results on dairy's specific effects.
population_specificity: Individuals who underwent physical examinations at Guangzhou Cadres Health Management Centre from May 2022 to May 2023.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of electrolysed water (EW) as a cleaning and disinfecting agent in clinical settings, contrasting it with existing healthcare cleaning approaches.
results_summary: The abstract notes a lack of evidence for EW's effectiveness in clinical settings, with existing publications mostly from laboratory or non-clinical environments. The paper proposes a risk assessment checklist for infection prevention professionals considering new technologies like EW.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus is on clinical settings, not a specific demographic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the diagnostic challenges of tuberculosis (TB) reactivation, particularly Mycobacterium bovis, in immunosuppressed patients and the importance of considering TB even in regions declared free of bovine tuberculosis.
results_summary: The study reported a fatal case of disseminated TB caused by M. bovis in a patient on TNFi therapy, emphasizing the limited sensitivity of IGRA and the need for detailed patient histories, including exposure to unpasteurized dairy products, to guide preventive TB treatment.
population_specificity: A 78-year-old woman with rheumatoid polyarthritis on adalimumab therapy.
interactions: TNF inhibitors (adalimumab) were noted to increase the risk of TB reactivation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of milk and dairy products on the risk and course of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), as well as patients' dietary beliefs and practices.
results_summary: The study found no clear evidence that milk and dairy products influence the incidence or course of IBD, with significant heterogeneity among studies. Many IBD patients commonly exclude dairy from their diets, which may have clinical implications.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how nutritional interventions, including dairy products, influence the acute bone biomarker response to exercise, particularly focusing on CTX-1 and P1NP.
results_summary: Dairy products were among the interventions studied, and calcium intake (from supplements, diet, or infusion) reduced exercise-induced increases in CTX-1, with larger effects observed via direct infusion. The study suggests that dairy and calcium may help protect bone health during acute exercise.
population_specificity: Healthy human populations of any age or training status.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between dairy intake and pediatric-onset multiple sclerosis (MS) outcomes, including relapse risk and disease progression.
results_summary: Increased dairy intake (50% above recommended levels) was associated with a 41% higher relapse risk and a 40% increased risk of T2 lesion progression. No associations were found with disability progression (EDSS).
population_specificity: 353 children with pediatric-onset MS (mean age 15.4 ± 2.9 years).
effective_dosage: 50% above recommended intake (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review existing literature to understand the relationship between dairy consumption and headaches, addressing methodological challenges and gaps in knowledge.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence regarding dairy's impact on headaches, with some studies suggesting a positive association, others showing no significant effect, and some indicating potential benefits from dairy restriction. Mechanistic insights suggest possible biological pathways linking dairy to headaches.
population_specificity: Individuals of all ages worldwide, with a focus on headache sufferers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic effects of vitamins D and K on cardiovascular and bone health in postmenopausal women, with a focus on dietary sources like fermented dairy products.
results_summary: The study found that combined intake of vitamins D and K positively affects cardiovascular and bone health in postmenopausal women, highlighting the importance of a diet rich in vegetables and fermented dairy products. Supplements are recommended due to dietary challenges in obtaining these nutrients.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dairy-derived proteins in mitigating chronic diseases and understanding their therapeutic potential.
results_summary: Dairy proteins were reported to offer promising benefits for managing chronic diseases, including cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, and bone health, likely due to their bioactive peptides and amino acids. The exact mechanisms remain unclear, but their nutritional and bioactive profiles contribute to these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population implied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the limitations of dairy as a probiotic delivery medium and assess alternative probiotic carriers, particularly cereal-based beverages, for African populations.
results_summary: The study highlights the limitations of dairy, such as allergens and lactose intolerance, and identifies traditional African fermented cereal-based beverages as promising probiotic carriers due to their fermentation process involving probiotic organisms.
population_specificity: African populations with dietary restrictions or cultural taboos against dairy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between dietary patterns, including dairy consumption, and bone health, focusing on prevention and treatment of bone-related diseases.
results_summary: The study found that calcium, vitamin D, and dairy products play an important role in preventing bone loss, though the abstract does not specify the magnitude of this effect. Other dietary patterns like high-sugar, high-fat diets negatively impact bone health more than mechanical load benefits.
population_specificity: Children, adolescents, and the elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dairy supplementation on bone acquisition in children's limbs through a clinical trial and meta-analysis.
results_summary: Milk supplementation significantly increased bone mineral density (BMD) and content (BMC) in the forearms and calcaneus, with beneficial changes in bone-related biomarkers. The meta-analysis confirmed these findings, showing dairy supplementation improved BMD and BMC in the arms but not the legs.
population_specificity: 315 children aged 4-6 years from Northwest China (278 completed the trial); meta-analysis included 894 children aged 3-18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess Spanish paediatricians' recommendations and opinions on dairy consumption and other nutritional practices for infants during the first two years of life.
results_summary: Most paediatricians agreed that two servings of dairy products daily are adequate in a diversified diet, and 93.4% opposed the use of vegetal beverages under one year of age. The study also highlighted general agreement on avoiding added salt and sugar before 12 months.
population_specificity: 245 experienced Spanish paediatricians
effective_dosage: Two servings of dairy products daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of animal milk and dairy products on human health, focusing on the Mediterranean area and Japan.
results_summary: The study found that milk and dairy products do not increase the risk of all-cause mortality, type 2 diabetes, or cardiovascular disease, and may lower the risk of chronic diseases. Some earlier studies reported harmful effects with higher consumption, but recent evidence supports their health benefits.
population_specificity: Mediterranean and Japanese populations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing dairy consumption to recommended levels adversely affects serum lipid profiles in older adults in aged care homes.
results_summary: The study found that increasing dairy intake did not alter serum lipid levels, suggesting it is a suitable intervention for reducing falls and fractures without negatively impacting cardiovascular health. No significant differences were observed in lipid profiles between the intervention and control groups.
population_specificity: Older adults (median age 87.8 years, 69% female) in aged care homes in Australia.
effective_dosage: Increased from 1.9 ± 1.0 to 3.5 ± 1.4 daily servings of milk, yoghurt, and cheese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the presence and transmission of Leptospira spp. in humans, rodents, and dairy cows in La Guaira State, Venezuela.
results_summary: The study found that Leptospira spp., including L. interrogans and L. venezuelensis, were isolated from dairy cows on a rodent-infested farm, suggesting a potential zoonotic transmission route. The same strains were also identified in human patients, indicating a possible link between dairy cow exposure and human leptospirosis cases.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with possible leptospirosis, local rodents, and dairy cows in La Guaira State, Venezuela.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of fermented dairy products on human nutrition and health, focusing on their potential benefits and probiotic properties.
results_summary: The study found that fermented dairy products offer various health benefits, including antimicrobial, antimutagenic, anticarcinogenic, and antihypertensive effects, as well as improvements in mineral metabolism, lactose intolerance, cholesterol levels, type 2 diabetes, and allergic symptoms. Probiotic strains in fermented dairy were also linked to positive health outcomes.
population_specificity: General human population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the enzymatic activity and biofilm formation profiles of Candida kefyr isolates from clinical and non-clinical (including dairy) sources.
results_summary: The study found that esterase activity was predominantly identified in dairy samples but absent in hospital samples, while other enzymatic activities (proteinase, haemolysin, caseinase, phospholipase) and biofilm formation varied between clinical and non-clinical isolates.
population_specificity: 66 Candida kefyr isolates (clinical and non-clinical, including dairy samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the epidemiology and trends in hospitalizations due to food-induced anaphylaxis (FIA) in Spain, with a focus on identifying common food triggers, including dairy.
results_summary: Dairy products were identified as the most frequent food trigger for FIA, accounting for 19.39% of cases. The study found that FIA incidence increased significantly among children, with dairy being a notable contributor to severe cases.
population_specificity: Spanish population, analyzed by gender and age groups (children <15 years, adults 15-59 years, and elderly ≥60 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dairy consumption and nutrient supplementation (calcium, vitamin D, etc.) in preventing hip fractures, particularly in elderly populations.
results_summary: The study found that dairy consumption has a protective role against fractures, and the combination of calcium and vitamin D supplementation significantly reduces hip fracture risk, especially in older and institutionalized subjects.
population_specificity: Elderly subjects, particularly those older than 65 with hip fractures or at risk of fractures.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed potential risk factors for Parkinson's Disease, including the role of dairy products.
results_summary: The study identified some dairy products as potential risk factors for Parkinson's Disease, though no specific mechanisms or causality were detailed. The abstract does not provide conclusive evidence but suggests a possible association.
population_specificity: General population (epidemiologic review, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence and nutritional quality of dairy in lunches brought from home (LBFH) by children compared to school-provided lunches.
results_summary: Dairy was found in 25% of LBFH, which was less prevalent than fruits but more common than vegetables. LBFH had lower levels of calcium compared to school lunches.
population_specificity: US school children bringing lunches from home.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential phytoconstituents from traditional Indian medicinal plants that could effectively combat Mycobacterium avium subspecies paratuberculosis (MAP), a dairy-borne pathogen linked to Johne's disease in ruminants and Crohn's-like disorders in humans.
results_summary: The study identified 70 potential medicinal plants, with seven showing strong anti-MAP properties, and proposed a novel phyto-paratuberculosis mechanism based on ethnopharmacological evidence. The findings suggest these plants could serve as alternative or adjuvant treatments for MAP-related disorders.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on in vitro, cell lines, and in vivo studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the current knowledge, concerns, and clinical impact of lactose malabsorption and intolerance in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that older adults are at high risk of malnutrition due to reduced dairy consumption, which can negatively affect muscle and bone health. It suggests a personalized approach to managing lactose intolerance in this population to avoid overly restrictive diets.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (older adults)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dairy nutrients and active ingredients in maintaining bone homeostasis, focusing on the dairy matrix effects and their associations with osteoporosis prevention.
results_summary: The study found that dairy components like lactose, proteins, vitamins, fatty acids, oligosaccharides, and exosomes work synergistically with calcium to enhance its bioavailability and utilization, potentially reducing osteoporosis risk. It also highlighted the benefits of probiotic/prebiotic, low-fat/high-fat, lactose-free, and fortified milk for bone health across different life stages.
population_specificity: General population, with specific attention to adolescents and the elderly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased calcium intake from skimmed milk, combined with an energy-restricted diet, would reduce glycation markers and improve metabolic control in adults with type 2 diabetes, overweight, and low habitual calcium intake.
results_summary: High-calcium intake (approximately 1200 mg/day) reduced serum advanced glycation end products (AGEs) and the AGE/sRAGE ratio. Positive changes in glycation markers were associated with worsening lipid profile, insulin resistance, and adiposity markers, suggesting the AGE/sRAGE ratio may be a better metabolic marker than AGEs or sRAGE alone.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes, overweight, and low habitual calcium intake (<600 mg/day).
effective_dosage: 700 mg Ca/day (high-calcium group) or 6.4 mg Ca/day (low-calcium group), plus 800 mg dietary Ca/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current research on aflatoxin's impact on animal forage, dairy products, and human health, and explore potential treatments and preventive interventions.
results_summary: The abstract outlines the environmental stress of aflatoxin on dairy products and describes clinical syndromes linked to aflatoxicosis, highlighting proposed treatments and preventive measures to counteract its effects.
population_specificity: Animal (pig) models and in vitro cellular studies, with implications for human health.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of dietary medicinal plants and their derived products in managing bovine mastitis due to their anti-inflammatory and antibacterial properties.
results_summary: The study highlights that medicinal plants with anti-inflammatory and antibacterial properties could serve as effective treatments for bovine mastitis, overcoming limitations of current therapies like antibiotics and immunotherapy. It emphasizes the low toxicity and minimal resistance features of plant-derived compounds.
population_specificity: Dairy cattle affected by bovine mastitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Se-enriched probiotic derived from a traditional dairy product could accelerate bedsore healing and reduce inflammation in ICU patients.
results_summary: The Se-enriched probiotic significantly reduced the bedsore healing period by an average of 2.4 days and decreased bedsore size by an average of 7 mm compared to the control group.
population_specificity: ICU patients with stages I and II bedsore.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high dairy protein intake versus high plant protein and low protein on muscle function, metabolic health, sleep quality, and quality of life in older adults.
results_summary: Increasing protein intake by 20 g daily (whether dairy or plant-based) for 12 weeks did not result in significant differences in muscle function, body composition, metabolic health, sleep quality, or quality of life compared to the low protein group. Handgrip strength improved over time, but there were no significant differences between the dairy, plant, and low protein groups.
population_specificity: Healthy men and women aged 50 years and older.
effective_dosage: 20 g of protein daily (in high protein groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how modifying pH during dairy protein processing affects textural properties and protein digestion.
results_summary: The study found that altering pH in acid heat-set bovine dairy gels created divergent textural properties, which influenced protein digestion and amino acid availability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system likely).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risks of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) in dairy cattle due to antibiotic use and explore emerging strategies to mitigate AMR.
results_summary: The study found that antibiotic use in dairy cattle contributes to AMR, posing risks to humans and the environment. Emerging solutions like selective dry cow therapy and alternative treatments are in development but require further research.
population_specificity: Dairy cattle sector (veterinary and agricultural context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review analytical techniques for phospholipids (PL) in dairy products and explore their biological roles in dietary supplements and biomarkers.
results_summary: The study identified 1295 PLs across 8 subclasses in dairy products and reviewed the relationship between PL composition and processing factors, highlighting PL's significance in dietary supplements and clinical research.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on dairy products and their components)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate food intake, including dairy consumption, and assess factors affecting energy and protein intake in liver transplant waiting list patients.
results_summary: Dairy consumption increased over time (p < 0.05), but only 25.5% of patients met nutritional goals by the study's end. The study noted improvements in protein intake and other nutrients but did not isolate dairy-specific effects.
population_specificity: Patients on a liver transplant waiting list (55.0 ± 10.6 years; 72.3% male).
effective_dosage: Not specified for dairy (nutritional plan: 35 kcal/kg; 1.5 g/kg protein).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to verify the effectiveness of sports nutrition education based on self-determination theory (SDT) for improving dietary behavior in university athletes.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the SDT and control groups overall, but the SDT group showed a significant improvement in protein-related knowledge.
population_specificity: 36 male university rowers.
study_duration: Sports nutrition education was held three times.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate online dietary advice regarding phosphorus-specific nutrition therapy, including recommendations and restrictions related to dairy consumption for CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found that online dietary advice predominantly restricts high-phosphorus foods, including dairy, aligning with traditional low-phosphorus diets, but noted significant inconsistencies in recommendations. Phosphorus bioavailability and demineralization were rarely addressed.
population_specificity: People with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and their healthcare providers.
study_duration: Not applicable (study reviewed existing online resources)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of milk heat treatment (UHT vs. pasteurized) on gastric emptying and circulating nutrient appearance in blood.
results_summary: Contrary to expectations, gastric emptying was slower with UHT milk, yet aminoacidemia was greater. The study suggests that gastric volume may poorly predict nutrient appearance from complex food matrices.
population_specificity: Healthy female habitual dairy consumers (n = 20; 27.3 ± 1.4 years).
effective_dosage: 500 mL of either UHT or pasteurized milk (1340 kJ vs. 1320 kJ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dairy products and their components on immune function and infectious disease outcomes, focusing on leukocyte and cytokine responses in humans.
results_summary: The study found mixed evidence suggesting that milk and yogurt drinks fermented with Lactobacillus strains may reduce the risk and burden of common infectious diseases, while probiotics showed potential benefits for gastrointestinal symptoms in HIV-infected persons and H. pylori eradication. No consistent changes in leukocytes or cytokine production were observed for dairy products, but probiotics appeared to enhance natural killer cell levels/activity and phagocytic processes.
population_specificity: Humans (general population and specific groups like HIV-infected persons).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connection between dairy consumption and the progression of hidradenitis suppurativa (HS).
results_summary: The study suggests that dairy could worsen HS symptoms, potentially through mechanisms linked to inflammation. However, the evidence supporting this connection remains weak, and dietary alterations alone are not considered independent solutions for managing HS.
population_specificity: Patients with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of dairy, as a protein-rich food, in preventing or treating sarcopenia by reviewing observational and intervention studies.
results_summary: Higher consumption of dairy was associated with beneficial effects on muscle strength in both observational and intervention studies, though evidence for other protein- and antioxidant-rich foods was inconsistent or lacking.
population_specificity: Older adults at risk of or experiencing sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the links between dairy intake and health outcomes, focusing on obesity, cardiometabolic disease risk, chronic kidney disease, and cancer, particularly among Black adults.
results_summary: Meeting or exceeding the recommended 3 daily servings of dairy foods is associated with better body weight, composition, and lower rates of chronic diseases. Fermented dairy (e.g., yogurt) and vitamin D-fortified dairy products showed the most protective effects.
population_specificity: Black adults, with a broader context including White populations from prior research.
effective_dosage: 3 daily servings of dairy foods (as per DGA recommendations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nudging strategies in an online supermarket could increase purchases of plant-based dairy and meat alternatives while reducing purchases of traditional dairy and meat products.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in dairy alternative purchases (IRR 1.00) and a 2% reduction in dairy product purchases (IRR 0.98) in the intervention arm compared to the control. The nudging strategies did not significantly alter dairy-related purchasing behavior.
population_specificity: Online supermarket customers (66% aged above 45 years, 67% female, 23% from socially disadvantaged neighborhoods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the Mediterranean and Japanese diets, including dairy consumption, to propose a hybrid diet for healthy longevity.
results_summary: The study noted that the Mediterranean diet includes significant dairy consumption, but did not specifically evaluate dairy's effects. The hybrid diet was suggested to reduce disease risk by suppressing chronic inflammation.
population_specificity: General populations in Mediterranean regions (e.g., Italy, Greece) and Japan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare muscle protein synthesis rates after ingestion of corn protein, a corn-milk protein blend, and milk protein alone.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study design suggests a focus on comparing the anabolic properties of these protein sources.
population_specificity: 36 healthy young males (26 ± 4 years).
effective_dosage: 30 g of each protein type (corn, corn-milk blend, milk).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how the chemical-physical properties of the dairy matrix and postbiotic effects influence the metabolomics response to fermented dairy consumption.
results_summary: The study found that heat-treated yogurt and acidified milk had similar effects on gut metabolic activity as yogurt consumption, suggesting comparable metabolic impacts.
population_specificity: 100 males with a BMI of 28.0-45.0 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of vitamin-D supplementation with milk or pharmacological calcium on bone mass accrual in underprivileged Indian children and youth with type-1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM).
results_summary: Supplementation with milk or pharmacological calcium (+vitamin D3) improved bone outcomes, particularly bone geometry, in children with T1DM, with a more pronounced effect in girls. Pharmacological calcium may be more cost-effective for optimizing bone health in resource-limited settings.
population_specificity: Underprivileged Indian children and youth (5 to 23 years old) with type-1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM).
effective_dosage: Group A received 200 ml milk + 1000 IU vitamin-D3/day; Group B received 500 mg calcium carbonate + 1000 IU vitamin-D3/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of oxylipins in regulating postpartum inflammatory responses in dairy cows and their potential implications for managing transition disorders.
results_summary: The study highlights that oxylipins, derived from PUFAs, play a key role in modulating inflammation during the periparturient period in dairy cows, but their potential as endogenous immunomodulators remains understudied. The review suggests further research is needed to understand their role in preventing inflammatory-based diseases.
population_specificity: Dairy cows during the periparturient period (transition from pregnancy to lactation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of tradipitant, a neurokinin receptor 1 antagonist, in reducing nausea severity in patients with idiopathic and diabetic gastroparesis.
results_summary: Tradipitant did not meet the primary endpoint in the intention-to-treat population, but post hoc analyses showed significant nausea improvement in subjects with high blood levels of the drug, particularly at weeks 2-4 and week 12 when accounting for confounding factors.
population_specificity: Adults with idiopathic and diabetic gastroparesis (n=201).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of dairy consumption on male fertility outcomes, including sperm parameters and clinical fertility measures.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent relationships between dairy consumption and clinical fertility outcomes (e.g., pregnancy rates, live birth rates). Limited evidence suggested dairy may improve sperm parameters, but results were not conclusive.
population_specificity: Men in the preconception period, including those undergoing fertility treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of homocysteine (Hcy) and its metabolic pathways, including dietary sources like dairy, in hyperhomocysteinemia (HHcy) and H-type hypertension (HTH).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about dairy's effects but mentions dairy as a dietary source of methionine, which influences Hcy levels.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of Hcy metabolism and related conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether fermented dairy products (yogurt) were superior to non-fermented dairy products in reducing liver fat and improving metabolic risk markers in males with abdominal obesity.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between fermented and non-fermented dairy products in reducing liver fat or improving metabolic markers. All intervention products caused modest favorable changes in some metabolic risk markers, but no group-specific effects were observed.
population_specificity: Males aged 30-70 years with a BMI of 28.0-45.0 kg/m² and abdominal obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare post-prandial muscle protein synthesis rates following ingestion of pea-derived protein versus milk-derived protein in healthy young males.
results_summary: The study found no difference in post-prandial muscle protein synthesis rates between 30 g pea-derived protein and 30 g milk-derived protein, despite milk increasing plasma essential amino acid concentrations more than pea protein.
population_specificity: Healthy young males (24 ± 3 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the metabolic effects of milk fatty acids, their relationship with metabolic disorders, and gut microbiota composition.
results_summary: The study found that milk fatty acids may influence metabolic alterations like obesity and cardiovascular diseases by modifying glucose homeostasis, inflammation, and lipid profiles. Evidence suggests no direct link between milk fat consumption and cardiometabolic risk, but further controlled research is needed.
population_specificity: General human population, with focus on metabolic disorders (obesity, type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the beneficial effects of probiotic Lacticaseibacilli (LAB) strains in non-dairy food matrices.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Dairy's effects, but it suggests a focus on probiotic LAB strains in non-dairy matrices.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the therapeutic potential of camel and mare milk in treating inflammatory rheumatic disorders, focusing on their anti-inflammatory and immune-regulatory properties.
results_summary: The study highlights that camel milk has notable anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and immunomodulatory properties, with potential benefits for inflammatory disorders. Mare's milk also shows therapeutic promise, though its effects on inflammatory conditions require further investigation.
population_specificity: General human consumption, with a focus on inflammatory rheumatic disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the limitations of dairy consumption due to lactose intolerance, allergies, and ethical/environmental concerns, and explore plant-based alternatives.
results_summary: The study found that dairy is linked to lactose intolerance and allergies, particularly in children, and identified plant-based beverages as viable alternatives with potential health benefits.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of children for allergic reactions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map intervention characteristics of lifestyle interventions for GDM prevention, including dietary components like dairy.
results_summary: The study identified low-fat dairy as a targeted nutrition component in GDM prevention interventions, but specific efficacy or outcomes related to dairy were not detailed.
population_specificity: Adults with obesity (mean age 31 years, BMI 31 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the occurrence of Aeromonas species in food, including dairy products, and assess their virulence, detection methods, and antimicrobial resistance.
results_summary: The study identified Aeromonas as a contaminant in dairy products, highlighting its pathogenic potential due to virulence factors and antibiotic resistance, posing a public health risk.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food and water sources, including dairy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing literature on bovine hemoplasmosis to understand its epidemiology, clinical signs, diagnosis, treatment, and impact on dairy cattle health and productivity.
results_summary: The study found that hemotropic mycoplasma infections in cattle are widespread but poorly understood, with unclear effects on health and productivity. Gaps in knowledge about disease pathogenesis, transmission, and management strategies were identified.
population_specificity: Dairy cattle infected with Mycoplasma wenyonii and Candidatus Mycoplasma haemobos.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the optimal dietary treatment for subjects with prediabetes, including the role of dairy products in their diet.
results_summary: The study recommended three portions of dairy products (milk/yogurt: 300-400 g/day) as part of a balanced diet for subjects with prediabetes, emphasizing their inclusion in the food pyramid for this population.
population_specificity: Adults with prediabetes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of milk fat with and without milk fat globule membrane and a vegetable fat blend on postprandial inflammation, focusing on blood monocyte gene expression.
results_summary: Consumption of cream with milk fat globule membrane downregulated inflammatory pathways in blood monocytes compared to anhydrous milk fat and a vegetable fat blend, suggesting an inflammation inhibitory effect of milk fat globule membrane. The vegetable fat blend increased inflammatory gene expression, while cream also downregulated energy metabolism-related pathways.
population_specificity: 37 middle-aged healthy male and female volunteers (BMI 22-27 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanisms underlying the effects of longer-term intake of fatty acid-modified dairy products (SFA-reduced, MUFA-enriched) on endothelial function in humans.
results_summary: The study found that plasma from participants consuming FA-modified dairy increased postprandial NOx production in HAEC but also upregulated E-selectin mRNA expression, with no impact on other genes measured. The results suggest a beneficial effect on NOx production but mixed effects on endothelial markers.
population_specificity: Eleven adults (age: 57.5 ± 6.0 years; BMI: 25.7 ± 2.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of an intervention on healthy offerings, including dairy desserts without added sugar, and the management of food allergies and intolerances in restaurants.
results_summary: The study found an increase in the offer of dairy desserts without added sugar in the control group, but no significant adverse effects or benefits specifically related to dairy consumption were highlighted.
population_specificity: Restaurants (intervention and control groups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of consuming dairy products as part of a common breakfast on postprandial aminoacidemia, glycemic control, bone metabolism, and satiety.
results_summary: Dairy consumption improved postprandial amino acid availability, glycemic control, and bone metabolism, with higher satiety observed when two servings of dairy were consumed. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 20 healthy young males and females.
effective_dosage: 1 dairy product (ONE-D) or 2 dairy products (TWO-D) as part of an iso-energetic breakfast.
study_duration: Single meal intervention with measurements up to 300 minutes post-consumption.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate biomimetic alternatives to antibiotics for managing bovine mastitis, focusing on their local application and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study highlights promising in vitro evidence for antimicrobial, antibiofilm, and antioxidant properties of probiotics, bacteriocins, bacteriophages, and phytochemicals, but notes limited in vivo studies and the need for effective drug delivery systems for clinical application.
population_specificity: Dairy animals (specifically cows with bovine mastitis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of dairy derivatives as a nutrition intervention for improving muscle-related components of sarcopenia in middle-aged and older females.
results_summary: The study found that dairy derivatives did not demonstrate any significant effect on muscle mass, strength, or function in the included RCTs. The results suggest that dairy alone may not be sufficient to impact sarcopenia-related outcomes in this population.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older females, particularly postmenopausal women.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a new PACE food label versus traffic light labels (TLL) on mothers' caloric choices, including dairy products.
results_summary: The study found that the TLL + brochure group selected foods with the lowest mean calories (831.77 kcal), while the PACE label group had the highest (971.61 kcal). The new PACE label did not significantly reduce caloric choices compared to TLL.
population_specificity: Mothers of school children aged 6-12 years in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of dairy in activating AKT/mTORC1 signaling and its implications in acne pathogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that dairy, as part of a Western diet, co-stimulates AKT/mTORC1 signaling, which enhances lipogenic and proinflammatory transcription factors, contributing to acne development. Isotretinoin counteracts these effects by promoting proapoptotic transcription factors.
population_specificity: Acne patients (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore improved methods for identifying novel dairy-derived angiotensin-I-converting enzyme inhibitory peptides (ANGICon-EIPs) and assess their potential as a supplementary diet-therapy for hypertension.
results_summary: The study highlighted advancements in deep learning-based peptide structure and function prediction, noting improved accuracy in identifying bioactive peptides. It also emphasized the potential of endogenous goat milk short-chain peptides as a source of ANGICon-EIPs.
population_specificity: Individuals with hypertension (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between serum ascorbic acid levels and immune system markers in hyperinsulinemia subjects consuming high or adequate dairy intake diets.
results_summary: Serum ascorbic acid positively correlated with immune system markers in hyperinsulinemia subjects, and a machine learning-derived protein signature could predict ascorbic acid levels. Dairy intake was adjusted for but not directly linked to outcomes.
population_specificity: 25 hyperinsulinemia subjects at risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: High dairy intake diet vs. adequate dairy intake diet (specific amounts not detailed).
study_duration: 6 weeks per diet phase, with a 6-week washout period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dairy products, among other dietary patterns, in preventing or slowing the progression of age-related cataracts.
results_summary: The study found that the "dairy products and vegetables" dietary pattern had significant protective effects against cataract incidence, along with skimmed yoghurt consumption showing positive effects.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals, particularly those aged 40 and above, at risk of age-related cataracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of bifidobacteria as probiotics in fermented dairy products and their impact on gut health and therapeutic benefits.
results_summary: The study found that bifidobacteria contribute to gut homeostasis by producing beneficial compounds like short-chain fatty acids and vitamins, though their survival in dairy products depends on various factors such as bacterial strain, fermentation parameters, and storage conditions. Fortification with bifidobacteria can also alter the physicochemical and rheological properties of dairy products.
population_specificity: General human population, particularly those consuming fermented dairy products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of the probiotic strain Lactobacillus plantarum MK06 on the treatment of gingivitis.
results_summary: The study found that while both the probiotic and placebo groups showed reductions in gingivitis clinical parameters, only the gingival index (GI) showed a significant difference in the fourth week. The probiotic group experienced a higher overall reduction rate in indices like BOP, GI, PI, and OHI-s.
population_specificity: Patients with gingivitis who were systematically healthy and referred to a private clinic.
effective_dosage: Lactobacillus plantarum suspension used for one minute two times a day after tooth-brushing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on the health claims associated with fructans (FOS and inulin) supplementation in human diets, particularly focusing on their benefits in dairy and other food products.
results_summary: The study found that fructans, such as FOS and inulin, improve glycemic control, promote beneficial gut bacteria growth, aid in weight management, and enhance immune function. They also serve as effective fat and sugar substitutes in dairy and other food products, improving texture and reducing energy content.
population_specificity: Human clinical trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate antibiotic residues in milk and dairy products and assess their potential health risks to humans.
results_summary: The study found that while most antibiotics in milk and dairy products posed negligible noncarcinogenic health risks to adults, children faced higher risks, particularly from quinolones. Quinolones accounted for nearly 89% of the health risks associated with all detected antibiotics.
population_specificity: Adults and children consuming milk and dairy products in China.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health effects of transportation on dairy bull and beef × dairy calves in the western United States, focusing on dehydration, blood glucose, lactate levels, and behavior.
results_summary: About half of calves had health abnormalities before transport, and over half were dehydrated after transport. Younger calves (<24 h) were more likely to be dehydrated compared to older ones.
population_specificity: Dairy bull calves and beef × dairy calves (n = 126) from two source dairies in the western United States.
study_duration: Observations were made before and after transport (within 2-3 hours pre-transport and ≤2 hours post-transport).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between socioeconomic status and health behaviors, including dairy consumption, in children and adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that children and adolescents from higher socioeconomic backgrounds exhibited a higher prevalence of health-promoting behaviors, including increased consumption of dairy products.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile and analyze literature on bioactive peptides derived from dairy, focusing on their potential roles in glycemic control, antihypertensive activity, and inhibition of uric acid formation.
results_summary: The study found growing interest in bioactive peptides from dairy for antidiabetic, antihypertensive, and xanthine oxidase inhibitory activities, with increasing research on non-bovine dairy sources. Peptides with low molecular weight and hydrophobic properties were highlighted for their molecular interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high dairy intake (≥4 servings/day) versus adequate dairy intake (2-3 servings/day) on blood pressure and arterial stiffness in hyperinsulinemic adults.
results_summary: The study found that neither adequate nor high dairy intake significantly altered blood pressure or arterial stiffness after 6 weeks. However, high dairy intake led to increased body fat, fasting insulin, HOMA-IR index, and triglycerides compared to baseline.
population_specificity: Hyperinsulinemic adults
effective_dosage: Adequate dairy (2-3 servings/day), high dairy (≥4 servings/day, actual intake 5.8 ± 1.9 servings/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether avoiding dairy products, as part of a macro-Mediterranean diet, could reduce breast cancer recurrence in high-risk patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in breast cancer recurrence from the dietary intervention that included avoiding dairy. However, higher compliance with the dietary recommendations (including dairy avoidance) was associated with a lower recurrence risk.
population_specificity: 1,542 women with breast cancer at high risk of recurrence due to estrogen receptor-negative cancer, metabolic syndrome, or high plasma levels of insulin or testosterone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare postprandial calcium absorption between a milk-derived calcium permeate (CP) and calcium carbonate (CC) in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that calcium carbonate (CC) resulted in higher serum-ionized calcium levels at 240 minutes and higher urinary calcium concentrations compared to the milk-derived calcium permeate (CP), indicating different metabolic responses between the two supplements.
population_specificity: 10 healthy postmenopausal females aged 50-65 years.
effective_dosage: 800 mg calcium from CP or CC provided in 6 capsules on separate days.
study_duration: Single-day intervention with measurements taken up to 360 minutes post-ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review associations between dietary patterns, including low-fat dairy, and male fertility outcomes such as semen quality and clinical fertility endpoints.
results_summary: The study found that dietary patterns including low-fat dairy were associated with better sperm quality, though evidence for clinical fertility endpoints like assisted reproductive technology success remained unclear.
population_specificity: Men, particularly those undergoing infertility treatment or trying to conceive.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate the most promising dietary biomarkers for dairy intake to improve accuracy in epidemiological studies.
results_summary: The study identified dairy biomarker candidates that are specific, have defined parent compounds, and are unaffected by nonfood determinants. Correlations with habitual intake were moderate to strong, but reproducibility over time varied.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population inferred from epidemiological focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess dietary intake patterns, including dairy consumption, and its association with nutritional status among children with cerebral palsy in Bangladesh.
results_summary: Dairy product consumption was lower among underweight children (48.8%) compared to others (51.2%), but the study did not evaluate dairy's specific effects or safety.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy in rural Bangladesh (mean age 3.6 years, 42.7% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the structure, composition, biological functions, and potential applications of milk-derived small extracellular vesicles (M-sEVs).
results_summary: The study found that M-sEVs have multiple bioactive benefits, including promoting intestinal, immune, bone, neural, liver, and heart health, as well as potential therapeutic effects against cancer. M-sEVs also show promise as natural delivery carriers due to their structural characteristics.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mammalian sources).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the clinical mastitis caused by L. lactis in dairy farming and discuss its characteristics and diversity, given its dual role as a probiotic and pathogen.
results_summary: The study highlights that while L. lactis is widely used as a probiotic for improving immune performance and intestinal balance, it has also been isolated from clinical cases, including mastitis in cows and infections in humans and animals. The lack of understanding of its pathogenic mechanisms poses a new challenge.
population_specificity: Dairy cows, humans, and other animals (e.g., silver carp, waterfowl).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a dietary intervention on the intake of dairy products among female Saudi Arabian adolescents.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased the intake of dairy products in the intervention group (P < 0.001), demonstrating a positive effect compared to the control group. No adverse effects or safety concerns related to dairy consumption were reported.
population_specificity: Female Saudi Arabian adolescents living in Arar.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate maternal dietary intake, including dairy, during pregnancy compared to the 2015-2020 and 2020-2025 Dietary Guidelines for Americans.
results_summary: Only 2.2% of participants met the recommended dairy intake, while 26.7% met the calcium intake. The study found poor adherence to dairy recommendations among women who gave birth preterm.
population_specificity: Women who gave birth to preterm infants between 25 1/7 weeks and 33 6/7 weeks of gestation.
study_duration: Dietary recall covered the last month of pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of dairy restriction in treating classic galactosemia and review current screening, clinical, and preclinical trials related to the disease.
results_summary: The study found that dairy restriction is a consensus treatment for classic galactosemia, though recent clinical studies suggest it could be reconsidered for the Duarte variant. The disease causes multisystemic damage, and preclinical trials are still needed to understand its pathophysiology fully.
population_specificity: Individuals with classic galactosemia and the Duarte variant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the nutrient composition, gut microbiota effects, and gut health impacts of organic versus conventional dairy products.
results_summary: Organic dairy products showed trends of higher omega-3 to omega-6 ratios, increased fat-soluble vitamins, and lower contaminants, potentially supporting nutrient uptake and reducing gut inflammation. However, direct human intervention studies are needed to confirm these effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of comparative studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dietary patterns in Puerto Rico, including dairy consumption, and assess their associations with metabolic syndrome and its components.
results_summary: Dairy was part of the "conventional" dietary pattern, but the study did not specifically isolate its effects. The neo-traditional diet (local plants and seafood) showed benefits, while industrialized starch and meat-centric diets had negative cardiometabolic effects.
population_specificity: Adults aged 30-75 in Puerto Rico (n = 989).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between whole-milk dairy consumption and cardiovascular disease risk, focusing on potential biological mechanisms and the role of the dairy food matrix.
results_summary: The study found that whole-milk dairy consumption does not increase cardiovascular disease risk despite its saturated fat content, suggesting potential benefits due to altered lipid metabolism, gut microflora influence, and anti-inflammatory effects. The dairy food matrix may play a key role in these outcomes.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from dietary guidelines and observational/clinical evidence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore dietary intake (macro- and micronutrients) and eating habits (location of consumption, electronic device use) pre- and post-intervention, and compare nutritional measures to current dietary guidelines.
results_summary: The study reported 822 consumed items, with most consumed at home, but no specific findings on Dairy's effects were mentioned.
population_specificity: 28 participants (secondary data analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to predict disease in preweaning dairy calves using automated milk feeder (AMF) feeding behavior data and machine learning algorithms.
results_summary: The study found that machine learning algorithms (random forest and gradient boosting) effectively predicted calf health status using AMF data and daily treatment records, outperforming weekly health scores alone. Implementing these algorithms could reduce the need for visual observation, improving efficiency and calf health monitoring.
population_specificity: Preweaning dairy calves on a farm in the Upper Midwest United States.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (behavioral data analysis, not a dosage-based intervention).
study_duration: Data collected from July 2018 to May 2019.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review lactose intolerance, its genetic causes, diagnostic methods, and potential treatments to prevent unnecessary dietary restrictions of dairy products.
results_summary: The study discussed lactose synthesis, catabolism, and intolerance types, highlighting genetic causes and diagnostic tests. It proposed current and future treatment solutions and dietary advice for lactose-intolerant individuals.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on lactose-intolerant individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize changes in rumination time, physical activity, and lying time in dairy cows before, during, and after diagnosis of metabolic-digestive disorders using an ear-attached sensor system.
results_summary: Cows with metabolic-digestive disorders showed significant alterations in rumination time, physical activity, and lying time compared to healthy cows, with patterns indicating potential recovery post-diagnosis. The ear-attached sensor system effectively detected these changes, suggesting its utility for early identification and monitoring of such disorders.
population_specificity: 820 lactating Holstein cows monitored from calving up to 21 days in milk (DIM).
study_duration: Daily monitoring from calving up to 21 DIM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize changes in rumination time, physical activity, and lying time in dairy cows before, during, and after diagnosis of metritis and clinical mastitis using ear-attached sensors.
results_summary: Cows with metritis and clinical mastitis showed significant alterations in rumination time, physical activity, and lying time compared to healthy cows, with more pronounced and prolonged changes in severe cases. Automated monitoring systems could aid in early identification of these conditions, and behavioral changes post-diagnosis may indicate recovery for metritis but not mastitis.
population_specificity: Lactating Holstein cows monitored for 21 days in milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify how glucocorticoids (GCs) affect mammary gland function and disease in ruminant animals, particularly in relation to milk production.
results_summary: The study found that GCs modulate mammary gland development before lactation, but excessive stress-induced GC release leads to milk production loss. Exogenous GC administration may alleviate mastitis symptoms, suggesting a dual role in both physiological and pathogenic conditions.
population_specificity: Ruminant animals (cows or goats)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the pharmacological activities and mechanisms of Hirsutine (HSN), a compound found in dairy and other foods, against various diseases.
results_summary: The study found that HSN exhibits anti-inflammatory, antiviral, anti-diabetic, antioxidant, and anticancer effects, but did not specifically address its effects in dairy.
population_specificity: Not specified (preclinical and pharmacological experimental systems).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze research productivity and scientific knowledge discovery related to COVID-19's impact on agriculture, including dairy, using bibliometric methods.
results_summary: The study identified COVID-19 and food nutrition from dairy and meat products as a major research theme but did not provide specific findings on dairy's effects.
population_specificity: Global research publications (1514 papers) from 2020 to 2022.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between preconception dairy consumption and fertility outcomes.
results_summary: The study found inconsistent results regarding dairy's effects on fertility, with no clear or consistent association demonstrated across the included studies.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age during the preconception period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a Mediterranean diet supplemented with dairy foods on the gut microbiome in Australians at risk of cardiovascular disease.
results_summary: The study found no change in the overall fecal microbial structure or composition with either the MedDairy or low-fat control diet. MedDairy-associated effects on bacterial relative abundance were correlated with clinical, anthropometric, and cognitive outcomes, but no significant overall impact was observed.
population_specificity: 34 Australian adults with systolic blood pressure ≥120 mmHg and risk factors for cardiovascular disease.
effective_dosage: 3-4 daily serves of dairy foods (Australian RDI of 1000-1300 mg per day).
study_duration: 8 weeks per diet, with an 8-week washout period between diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a high dairy protein diet combined with nutrition counseling and exercise on offspring neurodevelopment at 12 months of age.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the high dairy protein diet on neurodevelopmental outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant persons (>18 years, singleton pregnancy, BMI <40 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: High dairy protein diet (specific amount and frequency not detailed).
study_duration: Duration of intervention not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the use of antimicrobials and teat sealants in selective dry cow therapy (DCT) on Canadian dairy farms to understand current practices and potential for reducing antimicrobial use.
results_summary: The study found that 31% of farms adopted selective DCT, reducing antimicrobial use by approximately 50% compared to blanket DCT. Teat sealants were used on all cows by 56% of farms, while 12% used them selectively, with larger herds more likely to adopt them.
population_specificity: 144 dairy farms across 5 Canadian provinces (British Columbia, Alberta, Ontario, Québec, and Nova Scotia).
study_duration: Data collected between July 2019 and September 2021.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathophysiology, prevention, epidemiology, mitigation, cure, drug targets, and vaccine development for human brucellosis, particularly focusing on its transmission through unpasteurized dairy products.
results_summary: The study highlights that human brucellosis is primarily caused by consuming unpasteurized milk or dairy products, uncooked meat, or contact with infected animals, with outbreaks more common in developing and low- to middle-income countries. It also discusses potential drug targets and vaccine candidates for combating the disease.
population_specificity: Global populations, with higher risk in Asia, Africa, Eastern Europe, Mexico, South and Central America, the Caribbean, the Mediterranean Basin, and the Middle East.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review GRAS microbial species characterized as probiotics for producing nutraceuticals to alleviate discomfort and allergic reactions, particularly for lactose-intolerant consumers allergic to dairy products.
results_summary: The study highlights the potential of probiotic functional foods in improving gut microbiota ecology and reducing inflammation, particularly for individuals with food sensitivities. Non-dairy probiotic products are suggested as beneficial alternatives for lactose-intolerant consumers.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients and lactose-intolerant consumers allergic to dairy products.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of resveratrol (RSV) on metabolic abnormalities in dairy cows, focusing on its potential benefits and optimal dosing.
results_summary: RSV showed potential antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-obesity, and antimicrobial effects, improving reproductive performance and reducing methane emissions. However, high doses were associated with possible adverse effects, indicating dose-dependent efficacy.
population_specificity: Dairy cows in tropical regions experiencing metabolic stress.
effective_dosage: Optimal doses mentioned but not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of breakfast consumption (including dairy) versus skipping on cardiovascular risk factors and the role of functional foods like dairy in breakfast.
results_summary: The study suggests that breakfast consumption, including dairy as a functional food, aligns with chrononutrition principles and may support metabolic health, while skipping breakfast can contribute to a calorie deficit with potential cardiometabolic benefits for overweight/obese individuals.
population_specificity: Diverse patient populations, particularly those with overweight/obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-management intervention, including dietary modifications like increased dairy consumption, could improve metabolic syndrome risks in low-education women.
results_summary: The intervention improved the rate of meeting recommended servings for dairy products among other health foods, contributing to reduced metabolic syndrome risk factors. However, the abstract does not isolate dairy's specific effects from the broader dietary and lifestyle changes.
population_specificity: Low-education women aged 61 or older with metabolic syndrome and ≤6 years of education.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of steroid estrogens (SEs) in agro-food systems, including dairy, on plant responses and potential dietary risks to human health.
results_summary: The study found heterogeneous plant responses to SEs, with bioaccumulation highest in sand, followed by soil and hydroponic media. Food crops like carrot and potato were identified as major sources of SEs in the food chain, though health consequences remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 517 endpoints from various crop species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the role of dairy products fermented by lactic acid bacteria in mitigating allergic diseases.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that lactic acid bacteria in fermented dairy products may help reduce allergic diseases due to their distinctive proteolytic system, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify new criteria for estimating the effects of dietary supplements on sleep by examining relationships among supplements, pre-conditions, and sleep problems.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Dairy's effects, as the focus was on l-theanine and GABA.
population_specificity: 160 subjects with sleep problems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the genesis of clinical and subclinical endometritis in postpartum dairy cows, focusing on metabolic stress, immune dysfunction, and uterine microbiota shifts.
results_summary: The study found that up to half of dairy cows develop reproductive tract inflammatory diseases post-calving, with clinical endometritis linked to bacterial dysbiosis and subclinical endometritis associated with metabolic and immune dysfunction. These conditions, though distinct, commonly overlap and impair reproductive performance.
population_specificity: Postpartum dairy cows (3-5 weeks after calving).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the structure, biological activities, and potential health benefits of lactoferrin (LF) derived from dairy, including its antimicrobial, anti-viral, anti-cancer, and immunomodulatory properties.
results_summary: The study found that lactoferrin has diverse health-promoting effects, including protection against infections, mitigation of cellular senescence, and improvement of nutritional quality. It also demonstrated effectiveness against oxidative DNA damage, mitochondrial dysfunction, and various viruses and bacteria.
population_specificity: Not specified (general mammalian immune structures and potential clinical applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of reducing meat and/or dairy consumption on protein intake, anthropometric values, and body composition in adults aged ≥45 years.
results_summary: Reducing meat and/or dairy consumption significantly lowered protein intake but had no significant effect on body weight, BMI, waist circumference, body fat, or lean body mass.
population_specificity: Adults aged ≥45 years
